Bishop at prayer service urges Trump to ‘have mercy’ While delivering the sermon at Washington National Cathedral on Tuesday, the Right Rev. Mariann Budde directly addressed President Donald Trump in her plea for unity. “In the name of our God, I ask you to have mercy upon the people in our country,” she said to Trump at the prayer service. He sat feet away in the front row during the final official inaugural event. Trump told the nation Monday that he saw divine intervention in his restoration to the White House. “I was saved by God to make America great again,” he said, referencing the assignation attempt against him in Pennsylvania. Appearing to reference that statement, Budde called on Trump to help those fleeing war zones, to have mercy on children who “fear that their parents will be taken away” and to consider the “gay, lesbian, transgender children in Democratic, Republican and independent families, some who fear for their lives.” This was not the first time Budde, the Episcopal bishop of Washington, has directly addressed Trump’s language and conduct. She was among those who in 2019, during Trump’s first term, wrote a statement that read in part, “After two years of President Trump’s words and actions, when will Americans have enough?” A year later, Budde said she was “outraged” when federal officers used force to clear a crowd of peaceful demonstrators from the street between the White House and St. John’s Church, apparently so Trump could visit. “Everything he has said and done is to inflame violence,” Budde told The Washington Post at the time. “We need moral leadership, and he’s done everything to divide us.”
